												Honestly, the game completely lacks any and all substance. It's bland, forgettable, boring and tedious.     In the game, you play as an unnamed adventurer/trader, that sets forth to do one thing, become the Master Trader of the known universe/galaxy. One of the first missions is to find some chick that will give you a million credits on loan in order for you to buy a ship and start trading. You have a deadline when to get the million credits needed, and this formula repeats itself several times throughout the game, so much so that even the multiplayer is basically only that. Oh, and no one plays the multiplayer. In order to GET the million credits, you have to buy some commodities on Earth, and go to the Moon (which is just clicking a button) and selling your merchandise. Or you can do contracts. More on that later.      The trading system is very simple. You get to one of the merchants, you see the commodities they have for sale, and you buy it. There is a bar graph showcasing whether the market price for the item is declining or not, however the graph is pretty much nonsense, seeing as there's no trend whatsoever, and seems to be entirely, 100% random. To add to that, the trading is a pretty pathetic source of income, as even if you get lucky, you won't really earn a huge profit on anything you sell.      You can also find random commodities strewn throughout the worlds you find yourself, so there's no real reason to actually BUY commodities, as you'll find some semi-valuable stuff just laying on the floor in the map, free for the taking. Items range from wool to fetuses and radioactive metals and whatnot, and the "illegal" stuff is more valuable than the legitimate trading commodities. The game doesn't punish you for owning or selling illegal commodities, which was a wasted opportunity for some amusing gameplay as an actual smuggler. Shame.        The second source of money is through doing contracts or helping people out with arduous tasks. To get a contract, you have to go to the bar, where the barman will give you a target which you have to kill. This is where the game gets a slight instance of gameplay, by introducing an FPS arena, however, this falls flat as well, because the gunplay is so barebones it physically hurts to play through the FPS stages. The missions where you help people out aren't much better, as the case often is that you're simply collecting or buying X commodity and bringing it to some random dude or chick. Again, incredibly tedious.Also, the game came out 2008 if I'm not wrong. I originally thought it came out around 1999, when Freelancer came out, but holy♥♥♥♥♥♥2008????????????????????????????????       The music is obnoxious and not memorable in any way (read: elevator music), it features abysmal graphics, the little mechanics the game has are horribly unrefined, the economic system is non functioning, trading is next to useless unless you get some very rare, expensive commodities from missions, and the entire game feels like a chore.Overall, I'd give it a 3/10, would not recommend unless you have literally nothing else to do in your life.

												Space Trader Merchant Marine is that strange situation where two very different genres have been combined together in the hope of hitting that once in a lifetime combination that everybody agrees is pure genius, like Vampires and Teenagers, or Ninjas and Cheerleaders. Space Trader doesn't quite hit that special recipe however.Space Trader is a combination of a numbers trading simulator and a first person shooter and by far and large the biggest problem is that playing the game you have trouble telling which of these two aspects feel the most tacked on.The trading part of the game is simple enough. You travel between various planets in the solar system, each planet has a a few merchants each selling a few goods. You buy as much as your bank account and cargo space will allow and then travel to the next world. Space Trader has no real in game economy however and everything is decided by the almighty Random Number Generator. The challenge of choosing which products to buy is virtually non-existent as all items for sale lists how below normal market value they are next to their name. There is also a legal/non-legal system in place however it has no real effect in game making the actual buying and selling of products extremely dull and predictable.You explore the various locations on foot, in a first person shooter aspect. The various trade hubs allow you run around a small area, collecting various sellable items littered about the place, trade with the local merchants and take on a number of missions. The missions mostly come down to "Bring X items", "Transport X items" or, the more common, shooter mission. The majority of the missions in the game, and perhaps one of the easiest ways to make money early on in the campaigns is the various bounty missions which are your basic FPS. You spawn in one of a few predetermined maps, kill a few henchmen and eventually a boss will spawn. All the while you can pick up loot that you can sell out in the proper game, and weapons, health and shields that'll help you on this mission only. The shooting is fairly poorly implemented, even for it's time. The weapons feel like pellet guns, the enemy AI is non-existent and the whole experience usually boils down to just sniping at enemies from around a corner.The music throughout the game is a high speed techno beat that, while I am sure some of you will love it, made me play with the sound off after a few sessions. There is no voice-acting and very little ambiance. Even gun shots and hit sounds leave much to be desired. Graphically the game is nothing to write home about but not much below what you would expect from an indie title either.All in all, Space Trader Merchant Marine is a game that tries to do two things and fails at doing either in an acceptable fashion. It's not a very good trading simulation and not a very good shooter. It doesn't sound or look very good and it doesn't feel very good. This is a game that can easily be skipped.

												PresentationSteam Sales are always a great way to buy more games than you'll ever be able to play, but between all the big purchases you will often find some random games to keep you busy when there's nothing else; Space Trader: Merchant Marine is exactly that kind of game, but unlike most small, indie games this one managed somehow to keep me around more than it should have, just because at its core, it's an addictive experience. The premise of the game is simple: you are a new trader trying to find your way in this business and since you don't own a ship yet you need to find someone who is willing to give you one. What follows is a simple story and you will see the little twists coming from miles away, but even with that in mind, the missing excitement of what's going to happen next isn't the thing that will keep you around. The campaign has only five chapters and once you understand the mechanics of the game you will have no problem making millions from trading food stamps, oil or even organs. This game simulates the stocks trades perfectly, following the same: buy low, sell high premise, and even though at first it may be hard to figure out how to make all those millions, once you get the idea, it will be only profit for you from that point on. There's no real reward for doing this except the fact that once you reach a goal you will advance to the next chapter and start all over, trading between different planets, but that little sense of advancement is what will keep you playing.Rating: 5.5GameplayThe gameplay in Space Trader is pretty straight forward: you start on a planet and you have to buy commodities that will bring a profit and travel to another planet to sell them at a higher price, keeping a constant watch on the time limit that each mission has, calculating the profit per shipment and the travel time in order to choose the best option. Finding good deals is easy since those always have a gold star indicating that you should buy them, so eventually it becomes just a matter of having enough money in your pocket or enough cargo space, and your only enemy becomes the time as you carefully have to choose where to sell the stuff you just bought. You can make money by taking bounty missions from bartenders or by completing small tasks for different people, so it's always a good idea to talk with everybody because you might find out some interesting things or take on some missions that will give you some extra cash. The shooting mechanic feels old, but that's probably why it feels so addictive at the same time, as you will most likely instantly connect the dots between those shooting sequences and games like Doom, and even though all those bounty missions will get boring pretty soon as each map looks and feels the same and there are only two to three different types of enemies plus the target that you're supposed to assassinate, it is a good distraction from the boring buy and sell mechanic that the game generally delivers.Rating: 6GraphicsIf you look at this game you will assume it was released in the early 2000's because it looks like it was made a generation ago; from the simple and stiff characters to the environments everything looks pretty bad and the repetitive level design doesn't help either. By the end of the game you will know every corner of each planet, you will start to love a certain section for how easy it is to complete a combat mission and you will hate another for how difficult it is.Rating: 5AudioThe sound in this game ain't exactly bad, but it's simply mediocre at best. The voice acting is horrible, but the soundtrack manages to save it sometimes, especially in the heat of a battle, but otherwise there is nothing that stands out, it simply gets boring as you will end up ignoring the other characters or laugh at how bad they sound no matter the serious, story essential thing they just said. There are intentional comic lines too, such as the robot that answers by saying WTF, but those only make the entire thing feel worse, as the game is undecided between trying to be serious and making fun of itself.Rating: 5ExtrasAfter completing the main campaign you can also try the challenge mode that offers three extra missions that are pretty easy to complete and the only real challenge comes when you try to get the achievements, and if you're into that the game can get interesting and it has even some decent replay value as you can spend up to 18 hours struggling to complete everything. It's also supposed to have a multiplayer mode, which puts you and a friend in a race to get the most cash from those challenge missions, but after an hour of banging my head against the wall I couldn't figure out a way of making it work.Rating: 5VerdictWhen a game is getting such a low score no one would actually recommend buying it, but in this case I'll make an exception: you should give it a try if it's on sale and you can get it for less than an euro, as for that amount of money it will keep you busy more than enough to justify the purchase. It is in no way a great game, one that you will remember after leaving it aside, but as long as you play it you will be entertained simply because it's so stupid it becomes like a good parody.Rating Overall: 5.3

												Okay.Yes, it's an 'old' game from five years ago, so you can argue that the graphics shouldn't be expected to be cutting edge...but the modelling and textures and the like look considerably WORSE than Unreal - a game that came out _ten_years_before_ Space Trader: Merchant Marine.I admit that I'm a fan of Elite-style games: a hybrid of space flight/combat and trading simulation - WC:Privateer, X: Beyond the Frontier, Freelancer, Frontier: Elite II, etc....this is NOT that type of hybrid, despite the implication of the title. This game tries to weld FPS and trading together, and does NOT do a very good job with EITHER.1) The trading is simplistic, static and easily exploited.For each 'sector', there are a small handful of commodities, only a similar number of bases/trading hubs to buy and sell the same at, so you could probably chart out all the prices on a Post-It™ note...or even commit the best 'trading routes' to even a dodgy, old and  forgetful memory.And you won't have to worry about breaking the economy with your efforts - apparently each base has such large demands and supplies of EVERY commodity that even a huge shipment moved by yourself has NO effect on prices on either end of your run.  Your only restriction to making money is finding the best profit margin, and the size of your cargo hold (& working capital)....but hey; you don't even really need to worry about trading to get up these thinly-justified goals for earning - a) you can usually find piles of items just sitting in nooks and corners on the trading hub maps, which you can then sell to collectors for a decent starting stake, b) you can also pick up a considerable amount of cash from doing the bounty (aka FPS) missions - not always from the up-front wages of that, but from looting commodities from the 'hideout' of whatever low-life you're supposed to assassinate.2) As others have said, the FPS is similarly unchallenging - the maps are limited in quantity and variety, the 'power ups' are uninspired (and ephemeral), and the opposing AI is laughable, resulting in no point in any gameplay strategy apart from sneaking quickly to a good vantage point and then sniping everyone just aimlessly standing around.As such, you have two poor component-games, that barely feel like they should even belong together; the overall story is threadbare and challenges even the most credulous willing suspension of disbelief.Normally, I have very low standards to play a game (gfx, music, v/o, story, etc.) but this game managed to sink below even those unchallenging requirements.Do not even bother with this on a steam sale - the ONLY reasonable justification I could say for buying this game would be to bump up your XP from sheer quantity of game-ownership, and even then, a heavy discount would be necessary....but even so, I would under NO account EVER suggest you PLAY this 'game'...

PresentationSteam Sales are always a great way to buy more games than you'll ever be able to play, but between all the big purchases you will often find some random games to keep you busy when there's nothing else; Space Trader: Merchant Marine is exactly that kind of game, but unlike most small, indie games this one managed somehow to keep me around more than it should have, just because at its core, it's an addictive experience. The premise of the game is simple: you are a new trader trying to find your way in this business and since you don't own a ship yet you need to find someone who is willing to give you one. What follows is a simple story and you will see the little twists coming from miles away, but even with that in mind, the missing excitement of what's going to happen next isn't the thing that will keep you around. The campaign has only five chapters and once you understand the mechanics of the game you will have no problem making millions from trading food stamps, oil or even organs. This game simulates the stocks trades perfectly, following the same: buy low, sell high premise, and even though at first it may be hard to figure out how to make all those millions, once you get the idea, it will be only profit for you from that point on. There's no real reward for doing this except the fact that once you reach a goal you will advance to the next chapter and start all over, trading between different planets, but that little sense of advancement is what will keep you playing.Rating: 5.5GameplayThe gameplay in Space Trader is pretty straight forward: you start on a planet and you have to buy commodities that will bring a profit and travel to another planet to sell them at a higher price, keeping a constant watch on the time limit that each mission has, calculating the profit per shipment and the travel time in order to choose the best option. Finding good deals is easy since those always have a gold star indicating that you should buy them, so eventually it becomes just a matter of having enough money in your pocket or enough cargo space, and your only enemy becomes the time as you carefully have to choose where to sell the stuff you just bought. You can make money by taking bounty missions from bartenders or by completing small tasks for different people, so it's always a good idea to talk with everybody because you might find out some interesting things or take on some missions that will give you some extra cash. The shooting mechanic feels old, but that's probably why it feels so addictive at the same time, as you will most likely instantly connect the dots between those shooting sequences and games like Doom, and even though all those bounty missions will get boring pretty soon as each map looks and feels the same and there are only two to three different types of enemies plus the target that you're supposed to assassinate, it is a good distraction from the boring buy and sell mechanic that the game generally delivers.Rating: 6GraphicsIf you look at this game you will assume it was released in the early 2000's because it looks like it was made a generation ago; from the simple and stiff characters to the environments everything looks pretty bad and the repetitive level design doesn't help either. By the end of the game you will know every corner of each planet, you will start to love a certain section for how easy it is to complete a combat mission and you will hate another for how difficult it is.Rating: 5AudioThe sound in this game ain't exactly bad, but it's simply mediocre at best. The voice acting is horrible, but the soundtrack manages to save it sometimes, especially in the heat of a battle, but otherwise there is nothing that stands out, it simply gets boring as you will end up ignoring the other characters or laugh at how bad they sound no matter the serious, story essential thing they just said. There are intentional comic lines too, such as the robot that answers by saying WTF, but those only make the entire thing feel worse, as the game is undecided between trying to be serious and making fun of itself.Rating: 5ExtrasAfter completing the main campaign you can also try the challenge mode that offers three extra missions that are pretty easy to complete and the only real challenge comes when you try to get the achievements, and if you're into that the game can get interesting and it has even some decent replay value as you can spend up to 18 hours struggling to complete everything. It's also supposed to have a multiplayer mode, which puts you and a friend in a race to get the most cash from those challenge missions, but after an hour of banging my head against the wall I couldn't figure out a way of making it work.Rating: 5VerdictWhen a game is getting such a low score no one would actually recommend buying it, but in this case I'll make an exception: you should give it a try if it's on sale and you can get it for less than an euro, as for that amount of money it will keep you busy more than enough to justify the purchase. It is in no way a great game, one that you will remember after leaving it aside, but as long as you play it you will be entertained simply because it's so stupid it becomes like a good parody.Rating Overall: 5.3Check the full review and a lot more about Space Trader: Merchant Marine at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=233

												Space Trader: Merchant Marine is a bipolar game.  On the one hand, it tries to capture gamer interest as a commodities trading game, where you would buy and sell different commodities seeking to make a profit.  Yet, the game developers seem to realize the major flaw with this game--it gets boring quickly.  So they made a hackneyed attempt to spruce it up by adding a bulky, vastly inferior First Person Shooter component with graphics that are reminiscent of Doom.  I think the developers should have focused solely on the trading aspect, because consumers do realize the commodity trading simulation is the major draw of this game, and certainly not the FPS aspect.  How would I improve the commodity trading aspect?  I would offer unlockable merchants when certain conditions are met (i.e. a million dollars worth of legit inventory, or x number of cargo holds added to your ship), or create another category of goods.  What about the trader's personal reputation? What if the trader's reputation changes over time, as he deals in certain types of goods, and that influences pricing of wares from the NPC merchants?  These are some simple ways to spice up the trading simulation, and I'm sure the game developers could implement these additions quite easily.As it stands now, the game will capture your interest only until you get bored and tired of the commodity trading aspect.  How long will depend on personal tastes.

The graphics aren't appealing, either. The characters look only semi-realistic, fitting into the "Uncanny Valley" making them look actually really creepy, and the world models are too blocky and low-res to be serious-looking. The story just feels like an excuse plot, too. This game is definitely NOT worth the $4.99 normal price. If anything, 50 cents feels just about right for the little time and effort that was put into this game. Seriously, there must have been NO playtesting at all on this. The only thing I do like is the trading, and even then it's not enough to save this game. 2/10.

You have limited time to reach the campaign's money goal (money disappears after chapter), and time passes depending on the distance you travel. Posted: August 27, 2014
												I couldn't resist picking this game up for 49 cents just to see how bad it was. I wasn't disappointed! Have you ever heard of that movie The Room? It's supposed to be the Citizen Cane of bad films. Well if that's true, Space Trader is the Mass Effect 2 of terrible space games.It's hard to even describe exactly what makes this game so bad. Some games are so buggy or broken or just unplayable that they accumulate terrible reviews. Not Space Trader, it works totally fine! I couldn't find a single bug. Its problem is just a complete lack of ambition at every level. Everything about it is just earnest, straightforward and completely incompetent. It's almost like it wasn't made by a person at all but by an outside observer of the human condition - someone who just fundamentally misunderstands why humans enjoy things. Like, I don't know, a Martian or a hyper-intelligent dog or a robot from an 80's movie.The main mechanic of the game is an arbitrage simulator, kind of like Drug Wars - you know, that game for the TI82 graphing calculator that you could play in math class without getting in trouble? The main difference is that in Space Trader, it's pretty much on autopilot since the game marks the good deals for you. Also it's not about drugs, it's about such exciting futuristic commodities as "Manufactured Goods" and "Copper Ore."The combat mechanic is even worse. It's floaty and unreal, like trying to go back and play an old sprite based shooter from 1993. True this isn't a brand new game, but it is from 2008. That's the year Bioshock came out. Think about that for a second. Space Trader's gameplay was out of date by over a decade even back then.I think my favorite ridiculous detail about the game is in the dialogue. They got the perspective wrong, so when you're talking to the lumpy NPCs, you seem to be at about their nipple level. Sometimes... lower. If you have two quarters burning a hole in your pocket and you want to see just how bad this game is, give it a shot. On the other hand, you could just use the quarters to do your laundry instead. The Room is available on Netflix if you need something awful to watch while you fold.

												This game had such an interesting premise, and such interesting potential. I wish I could reccomend it, but alas, it's faults outshine what it gets right. Despite the name of the game being "Space Trader", the most valuable and worthwhile jobs are actually bounty hunting jobs. And to say that the combat is lacking is an understatement. The campaign mode resets your progress at the end of each chapter, eliminating any cargo or money beyond the final objective that you managed to save, as well as eliminaing all incomplete quests. The idea of growth and becoming a better and more important trader should have carried, but because of the artificial reset, fell very flat. I stopped playing the campaign after seeing my progression removed for no reason.And the free for all mode is lacking: from what I can tell, there is a mode that is basically unlimited time and complete freedom, but in order to get it, you have to beat the first challenge which is impossibly difficult. If even one of these issues were different, I would consider playing again, as the premise is solid and fun, but the execution here is not worth the time.

												Long, long ago on a computer far away an enterprising game designer created a free program about the drug trade, and they called it 'DopeWars.' A bit shorter time ago I had a palm III and I got a game with the same name as this one, but it was a more conservative port of DopeWars with a bit of ship management added in.Now we have this latest entry into the 'trader' game pile, and I have to say I'm not exactly thrilled after nearly two hours of gameplay on just the first mission. This isn't to say that I don't see the potential, and I did have fun with the setup, but I noticed a few things that might be deal-breakers for those looking to just bounce around buying and selling.Firstly, you seem to make more money doing the side-quest shooter arenas that are basically fights against bots, quake 3 style, complete with respawning weapons and pickups. For a game about trading this seems a bit off message, but easy enough to let it slide, since it does provide a break to the actual game and gives you extra funds and inventory for trade.I think of it as something extra from what's on the tin.Second, extra cargo spaces are treated as a commodity, which makes no sense to me. They even fluctuate in price between planets so you could feasably make profit selling the only part of your ship that you can upgrade. This plays into my even bigger point, which is this game could benefit greatly from just a bit more effort in the space travel side of things. You go through this big setup as to the why and how of getting your ship, and the necessity of paying off the debt, but you never see this ship, nor any other. There is talk of space-pirates, but I doubt you really go into any sort of combat with them, unless it's another one of those bot-arena matches mentioned before. Plus it would be a great expense along with the cargo bays, something to use your money for. This calls back to the Space Trader from my palm iii days....maybe I'm just nostalgic.Third, the first mission itself, and a particular side-mission forced on you by the same person, aren't clear on how to complete. I was given the task of amassing a debt-payment of considerable size, which was easy enough, and given a bot-match that I complete as well, but they remained in my 'news' tab till the mission failed, reloading just dumps me back to the start. This appears to be a bit broken, surely in this future space universe we're dropped into, especially one with banks, you'd be able to make installment payments to pay off your debt if the challenge were more long term.As it stands, since the challenge has a short time frame, again it would make sense that the first thing you would be told to do after hitting the amount you owe in profit would be reminded that you have to pay it off, or at least told how you would go about satisfying the end condition. Maybe I'm just tired and it was blatantly obvious, I did write this up after basically struggling with it for two hours, and I haven't really looked into any guides or other solutions, but a game that presents itself so simplistically in places like this one shouldn't need a guide to finish the 'baby's first' challenge.Cutting this short (yes short, I can keep going) I'm giving this game a tentative recommendation based upon its current price and availability in a sales package, since for this much you get what you can expect, a game where you trade between planets in space, with a bit of bot-shooting added in for flavor, but if you're just looking for a trader without the fluff and semi-broken, non-intuitive bits to slog through there are plenty of free alternatives.

												Space Merchant is a game with an identity crisis. It is mainly a buy/sell stock market type video game of the future. It tries to incorporate first person shooter action as well. If you're looking for a market based game where you trade commodities based on their profits, this is your game. There are interesting characters to trade with a quite a bit to do. The voice acting is simply a joke. One of the most annoying sounds I've ever heard in my life occurs when you walk up to civilians and they say "later" or whatever it is. Makes me cringe every time! The tutorial was quite lacking, although I understand there is a fine line between innundating/confusing players with too much detail and letting them actually play the game. It will take you a couple times through to understand the nuances of it. For the first person shooter crowd, this is a definite pass. The "run and gun" aspect of this is simply a joke. There are three guns, a starter pistol, a shotgun, and a machine gun. Not exactly a wide selection by any means. When you pick up a new gun, some times the game will automatically switch to it, others it will not. This can be quite frustrating as you can imagine. Another issue is respawning location. You have 3 chances to defeat the bounty. The game randomly drops you off in locations, some times right by a henchmen. After a respawn, you stand very little chance defeating a well equipped good, meaning another chance wasted. The game randomly stops you midstride, which sucks if you're running away from someone who is shooting in your direction. Lastly, perhaps the biggest disappointment of all, there are no upgrades of any sort. You'd expect to improve your skills the more bounties you attempted or completed, but that is not the case. Every time is almost the same, making it quite repetitive. I'm rating this game as barely passable because I do enjoy playing it, despite its many flaws (mostly on the bounty hunter side).

												To be honest, I was expecting disappointment, especially because I got it free, but it is not too bad. Granted it isn't Game of the year... or even game of the month material, but it is not bad.The trading is pretty basic, the side-quests are alright, the main story line is kinda thought out, and the combat isn't TOO bad. You make money in a few ways. Finding around 50-100 items scattered around a trading port in the planets, all of which seem to have citizens that do not understand the concept of keeping their items, both legal and illegal, in their safety deposit boxes, or safes, or houses. You can also buy and sell items, go bounty hunting, or do some tasks for various people (including aquiring certain items or... you guessed it, killing people). The combat includes about 3-5 different maps (some of which are altered slightly in appearance) that, after a while get somewhat mundane. The trading in pretty simple, which is a plus for some, but also a minus for others who want to use certain strategies to be able to maximize their wealth beyond seeing what is in surplus or demand. The combat includes getting 3 chances to kill a certain number of enemies in order to have the boss arrive. You can go around and collect items that are left about, as well as get cash off the bodies of your slein enemies. One of the major flaws though is that after the boss is defeated, he drops a bunch of items, sometimes more than 20-30 boxes around him, that can be picked up. This wouldn't be so bad, in fact it would be terrific if it weren't for the fact that each set of 4 or so items leave a text on the screen that shows what they were for several seconds. That text has to dissappear before anything else can be picked up (even the money, which is sometimes in the 10s of thousands, and even more). If the money is in a stack of many items, it may take a while to get it. Which brings us to another problem, you only have 10 seconds to pick up all of your loot after the boss is killed. After that, you get nothing more. Kinda sucks. But anyways, I give it a 7.5/10, not too bad, but definitely has a large flaw or two in it. But oh well, I got it for free anyways.

												I genuinely don't understand all the negative reviews about this game.  The graphics are cutting edge for its time (even if the audio is cripplingly glitchy), the market mechanics are easy to understand and make sense, and the FPS element of the game is comparable to several others of its time, like Quake III: Arena - without the great multiplayer (which is the only thing about Quake III that actually *was* any good), and adding playing with commodity prices.   This game's multiplayer support was dismal, but as multiplayer was sort of an afterthought and not really what the game was about, I can forgive this.  I've played a lot of games where the single player campaign is good, and the multiplayer not so much.  Big deal.  Personally, I don't do a lot of multiplayer - meaning I don't live for it like other players, and my good review of a game doesn't depend on it having a good multiplayer mode, so it wasn't a major factor in my enjoyment of it.  When you design a game to be single player and add multiplayer support later in order to appease that crowd, it's always going to be lackluster at best.  Another thing others complained about was the price.  I got the game through Humble Bundle with a bunch of other titles for a very low price, so I don't really have a right to complain with the rest.  I'll be honest, by itself for 4.99 on Steam I probably would have never looked at it twice, but having got it in the bundle and trying it, I discovered that it's a decent game...though I honestly only kept playing it after I completed it in an attempt to get all the Steam achievements.  Difficulty isn't too severe - the market system is easy to figure out, and the FPS AI isn't particularly smart, though they do seem to have something approaching super-human aim (which is something that Quake III was also guilty of).  The challenges are actually fairly difficult to master, but the campaign is reasonably easy to defeat.  All this being said, I won't recommend the game - It's past its time.  I won't hate on it like others have - for its age, it's decent, but there's very little to attract my attention to it now.

												Long, long ago on a computer far away an enterprising game designer created a free program about the drug trade, and they called it 'DopeWars.' A bit shorter time ago I had a palm III and I got a game with the same name as this one, but it was a more conservative port of DopeWars with a bit of ship management added in.Now we have this latest entry into the 'trader' game pile, and I have to say I'm not exactly thrilled after nearly two hours of gameplay on just the first mission. This isn't to say that I don't see the potential, and I did have fun with the setup, but I noticed a few things that might be deal-breakers for those looking to just bounce around buying and selling.Firstly, you seem to make more money doing the side-quest shooter arenas that are basically fights against bots, quake 3 style, complete with respawning weapons and pickups. For a game about trading this seems a bit off message, but easy enough to let it slide, since it does provide a break to the actual game and gives you extra funds and inventory for trade.I think of it as something extra from what's on the tin.Second, extra cargo spaces are treated as a commodity, which makes no sense to me. They even fluctuate in price between planets so you could feasably make profit selling the only part of your ship that you can upgrade. This plays into my even bigger point, which is this game could benefit greatly from just a bit more effort in the space travel side of things. You go through this big setup as to the why and how of getting your ship, and the necessity of paying off the debt, but you never see this ship, nor any other. There is talk of space-pirates, but I doubt you really go into any sort of combat with them, unless it's another one of those bot-arena matches mentioned before. Plus it would be a great expense along with the cargo bays, something to use your money for. This calls back to the Space Trader from my palm iii days....maybe I'm just nostalgic.Third, the first mission itself, and a particular side-mission forced on you by the same person, aren't clear on how to complete. I was given the task of amassing a debt-payment of considerable size, which was easy enough, and given a bot-match that I complete as well, but they remained in my 'news' tab till the mission failed, reloading just dumps me back to the start. This appears to be a bit broken, surely in this future space universe we're dropped into, especially one with banks, you'd be able to make installment payments to pay off your debt if the challenge were more long term.As it stands, since the challenge has a short time frame, again it would make sense that the first thing you would be told to do after hitting the amount you owe in profit would be reminded that you have to pay it off, or at least told how you would go about satisfying the end condition. Maybe I'm just tired and it was blatantly obvious, I did write this up after basically struggling with it for two hours, and I haven't really looked into any guides or other solutions, but a game that presents itself so simplistically in places like this one shouldn't need a guide to finish the 'baby's first' challenge.Cutting this short (yes short, I can keep going) I'm giving this game a tentative recommendation based upon its current price and availability in a sales package, since for this much you get what you can expect, a game where you trade between planets in space, with a bit of bot-shooting added in for flavor, but if you're just looking for a trader without the fluff and semi-broken, non-intuitive bits to slog through there are plenty of free alternatives.

												The game has an interesting concept, merging a space trading game with some first person action elements and missions, and even a bit of mystery (Where the heck is Lieutenant Dan?), however it falls short on many levels.Firstly, as a trading game it is pretty weak.  The economy simulation has a very limited number of commodities and the pricing mechanics are reasonably predictable.  Go to destination A, buy the highest priced goods that have the most recent lowest price, possibly split the cargo hold between the two top picks, then travel to the next destination to hopefully (and almost always) sell it at a higher price then repeat.  It's fairly tedious, and there is no buy/sell commission/overhead so you just sell off your entire inventory whether it is a profit or loss, then buy up whatever is the best deal on the current planet even if it is one of the things you just sold them, fairly unrealistic compared to any other trading games I've played as there is no buy-ask spread whatsoever.  There are 5 missions in campaign mode and the first 4 are more or less like tutorials more than anything and have only 2 or 3 destinations which is pretty suboptimal for a space trading game really.  The real game is campaign mission 5 which has 4 destinations and a bit of a story to it (albeit a weak one).  The biggest mystery in the game is trying to find Lieutenant Dan, which is a bit challenging, but also rather disappointing when you do find him.You then go on contract hitman jobs to kill various bad guys you've been either sent to take out, or that you opted into by taking a job through the bartenders.  The contract hits are incredibly repetitive due to there only being about 3 or 4 small maps that they play out in.The FPS enemy AI is 1990s quality, and the action isn't that great.  The meat of the game is in mission 5 which is the longest and has the most trading destinations (4 total).  You're on a countdown timer from 500 hours with each travel you take consuming some number of hours with which you must meet the trading objectives.  Problem is, from the start you can't trade anywhere due to a military presence halting trading, so you have to travel around to make money from hit jobs to then pay off the authoritarian police state guys to leave so trading can resume.The rest of the time you end up running around the levels collecting crates full of random commodities like Super Mario and selling them.  It's very tedious and gets boring quick.I finished this game just to see if there was anything at all exciting about it, but it was somewhat disappointing.  If it is a space trading game you're looking for, this sure isn't it.
